comments.content: The trick is to use a thicker extension cord

Use industrial thick extension cord. They are usually orange. You can find them at Home Depot. They even have thick splitting cords. Just make sure you don't connect to many things or you will blow the breakers.
"Heavy Duty" extension cord from the hardware store.
Make sure the electrical cord has all three prongs too. The ones that don't are not grounded and will not work as good.
Most space heaters have a 1500 watt max rating. Try to find one with a low med high settings. Use the medium setting (usually 1000watts) Get a grounded extension cord with 12 gauge wire.

The more critical part of these two components is the extension cord. They sell fused ones and ones with breakers. I'd recommend one of those types. Also, the heater should give it's amperage (current) rating on the packaging. Make sure your extension cord can handle that current load.
https://www.greenoptimistic.com/kandle-heeter/#.WgHUd8aFTxo

You really are not supposed to use extension cords with heaters. If you do, use the shortest cord possible and at least 14 gauge wire (remember, the lower the gauge number, the thicker the wire). After it's plugged in and running, feel the cord  and make sure it's not getting hot.
This would warm up your garage studio in a heartbeat. Worth the 200 to keep you toasty warm.
An extension cord for an air conditioner is also heavy duty. I would advise against that propane or oil fired heater. They put out CO and you get bad enough headaches.
Layered clothes.  Sorry; don't trust space heaters.
12 gauge extension cord.

Get one of those oil filled electric radiators. They're thermostatically controlled and efficient. We used one for our potbelly pig's house outside of ours on an extension cord for 19 years with no problems.
propane heater

The people who said you need a cord to match the heater (not vice versa) are correct. Get one rated for 15 amps or more and you'll be fine (14 AWG wire or lower). Some also have a current limiter built in. That wouldn't be a bad idea, either. I've been an electrician for over 20 years. If you have any more questions, feel free to ask.
Radiant heaters are great and safer than the coil ones.

First off extension cords don‚Äôt have breakers it‚Äôs a gfci which is a good thing to have, it‚Äôs personal protection. Second #12 awg cord as short as you can get away with is best. If you run the heater on high the plug, the cord on the heater and where it plugs in the wall are your weak spots. That being said space heaters should always be monitored and not left alone.
Also these? https://youtu.be/n2OlphnNTvA
The first thing you need to think about is insulation to keep cold out & heat in and fire risk. Are your paints flammable?

If you have windows with solar exposure, you might be able to both insulate and take advantage of solar heating by double-glazing your windows. Certain types of plastic bubble wrap are great for building green houses, so should also provide both insulation and solar heating for a garage with sunshiny windows.
Just match the load capacity in amps of the heater to the extension cord. Probably about 13 amps.
It's about the amperage  so you need a contractor type extension cord that is meant to handle the high amps.

You could also have a receptacle installed closer to where you want it plugged in. In either case, 12 Guage copper conductor is what I'd go with. It may be overkill, but it's safe for up to 20 amps (to a certain length).
With a continuous load you should not exceed 80% load. 1500 Watts @ 120volts is 12.5 amps, 12amps is 80%.
Bottom line don‚Äôt run it on high and get a #12 awg cord.
I tried the heavy duty extension cord last year and my heater still died permanently after a couple months

Joan Hunter Iovino - These are the best types of space heaters, hands down. First, if you‚Äôre concerned about the price, they are usually cheaper at Walmart, Target, and hardware stores than this one is on Amazon (this one looks fancier than mine. Mine a ... See More
Get an infrared heater instead of a space heater, they're safer, they heat more effectively (because they heat you, instead of the air), and they don't dry out the air. $60 and up on Amazon.
You could also get an electrician to run a new circuit for your studio area.  It would allow you to improve your lighting as well as your heat.
I can atest to infrared heater sitting at your feet, you only need a tiny one and you will be super warm
The best yoga studios have infrared heaters. It cooks you internally, there's nothing like it.
Use the shortest, heaviest duty cord possible.
